title: Leptopus
text:
Leptopus, the maidenbushes, are a group of plants in the <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a> <a href="family%20%28biology%29">family</a> <a href="Phyllanthaceae">Phyllanthaceae</a> first described as a genus in 1836. As presently constituted, is native to southern <a href="Asia">Asia</a> from the <a href="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> east to <a href="China">China</a> and <a href="Maluku%20%28province%29">Maluku</a>.
"Leptopus" is one of eight genera in the <a href="Tribe%20%28biology%29">tribe</a> <a href="Poranthereae">Poranthereae</a> and comprises 9 <a href="species">species</a>. It is the <a href="sister%20taxon">sister</a> of "<a href="Actephila">Actephila</a>". The <a href="type%20species">type species</a> is "<a href="Leptopus%20cordifolius">Leptopus cordifolius</a>". The <a href="Botanical%20name">name</a> is derived from two <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a> words, "leptos", "thin, slender, or small", and "pous", "foot", a reference to slender <a href="Pedicel%20%28botany%29">pedicels</a>.
"Leptopus" consists of <a href="monoecious">monoecious</a> <a href="Herbaceous%20plant">herbs</a> and <a href="shrub">shrub</a>s with <a href="compound%20leaves">simple</a>, <a href="entire%20leaf">entire</a> <a href="Leaf">leaves</a> and small, green <a href="flower">flower</a>s. The genus was revised in 2009.
"Leptopus fangdingianus" had been placed by some authors in a separate genus, "Archileptopus", but it was shown in 2007 that recognition of "Archileptopus" makes "Leptopus" <a href="paraphyletic">paraphyletic</a>. "Phyllanthopsis phyllanthoides" has been placed in "Leptopus" as well as in "<a href="Andrachne">Andrachne</a>". In 2007, it was shown to not properly belong to either genus and in 2008 was assigned to a new genus, "<a href="Phyllanthopsis">Phyllanthopsis</a>".
